ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Database concepts
I learned how to use SQL and how database structures work.
SQL and database management skill as a data scientist
SQL language, database design

I learned a lot, much more than I was anticipating. I developed skills to design databases with the ER model, learned intimately about relational databases, normalization, serializability, hashing, and more. This is an excellent course.
database concepts and how to use sql language
Basic understanding of how to use SQL database
database, relation algebra, storage
mysql, database structure
DBMS, SQL, cache, storage, project...
Relational databases and their underlying structures.
Complex SQL query, light-weighted framework database development and other database system algos

By taking this course, I developed a comprehensive understanding of database systems, including data modeling, SQL, and relational database design. I also gained practical skills in implementing databases, through the semester-long project.
database systems and structure
Nothing
Basic relational database features, database normalization

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its good

A strength of this course was the variety of material that was covered.
A weakness of this course was the final project. It was unclear what was expected of the final project.

The knowledge is clear and the book is good.
The homework assignments are terrible, usually HWs are used for students to strengthen their knowledge, but these homework make me feel that I am not using my brain but hurting my hands. There are two many questions that let use doing repeating work, it's quite tortured when you need to repeat a algorithm 10 times by drawing plots or images like hash tables/B tree etc. Also, questions are ambiguous and TA's answers are wrong sometime, and TAs can't really make them clear and correct.
Lectures and slides are hard to understand if you don't have any prior knowledge of database.
Strengths are the homework assignments. The course would benefit a lot from programming assignments.

Strength: low workload, everything covered in class can be found in slides and textbook
Weakness: very unexciting, the professor does not try to make this class engaging. 
I don't think it's gonna get improved. Prof Silberschatz has taught this for years.
grading percent could be adjusted.
good thing abt this course is that the material itself is super important and can help you a lot in a SDE job interview. Workload is low compare to other CS courses
the course is quite difficult for beginners
It is not well organized at all. We get no practice problems at all. The psets are not like the exams.

The lectures were disappointing. It was difficult to hear Avi because he never used the microphone and often makes mistakes regarding the lecture slides making for confusing explanations. 
The assignments were useful in making up for this missed knowledge, at least. Expect to learn while doing the homework instead of before.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The concepts are interesting.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in database design.
No, the knowledge is important, but the HWs are terrible
Yes. Generally we can learn a lot throughout the course. And honestly most computer science courses will not cover the materials that are covered in this course.
I would highly recommend every student at Yale studying computer science or a related discipline take a course in databases, so yes.

No. The lectures are boring, I stopped going after a week. There are so many mistakes in psets and solutions, the TAs often release multiple versions of each pset because of corrections are needed. The exams are badly-written, no problem solving involved, straight up concept memorization. If you want to take a gut CS elective, take something else. I truly regret taking this, even though I spent minimal time on this class and got a decent grade.
yes
yes, great course
I would say yes for those who are interested in how database works instead of those who only wants to know how to use database.
no this class was horrible. One of the worst classes I have ever taken at Yale.
yes. the content was good and beneficial
No. Especially if you have not taken the prereq.

No. I came into the course thinking I would gain a greater understanding of databases and its current applications but the information seemed like rote memorization of methods to apply to some data similar to applying a formula to a mathematical problem without understanding the underlying reasoning. Better off self-studying or working with practical database systems yourself.
